feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A flowchart is a conceptual diagram, not a tangible object.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Flowcharts are constructed using agreed-upon symbolic conventions.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — There is no biological basis in its structure or logic.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — While instances may be fixed, the concept itself is abstract and modifiable.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It does not have a physical or material structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Included — A flowchart is explicitly visual and designed to be seen and interpreted.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — The diagram is abstract; it may be drawn on material, but is not material itself.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — The concept of passivity is not meaningfully applicable to a static diagram.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Created with the intent to convey process logic or workflow.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not intrinsically generate output.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It represents processing but does not execute logic.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It has no internal state to change.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Included — Designed for humans to view, interpret, and use in real-time.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — While often embedded in documents or systems, its identity is not system-bound.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — It requires interpretation; does not operate independently.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Rarely a critical system component; a tool for understanding and design.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Encodes logic or decision flows using abstract symbols.
feedback.Communicative: Included — The primary purpose is to communicate structure or logic.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Follows conventions like decision trees, branching logic.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Can represent nested or modular processes.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Used to instruct or constrain actions (e.g., in training or design).
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Does not describe or encode itself.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — It shows sequencing but is not inherently time-based.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Meaning can change across software engineering, business analysis, etc.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Diagram conventions arise from shared technical and communicative norms.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Standardized symbols are maintained by technical communities.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — A flowchart does not define the identity of users or groups.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — No institutional regulation governs flowcharts directly.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Widely taught in education and training contexts.
feedback.Visible: Included — Its utility depends on being visually rendered and interpreted.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Interpretation depends on the domain (software, logic, business modeling).
feedback.Widely known: Included — Commonly used across technical and educational fields.

encoding_notes: This corrected encoding positions the flowchart as a visual symbolic representation of logical processes. It is primarily abstract and social in nature, with a clear human interface. The updated UHT code reflects the full set of conceptual and social dependencies without introducing unjustified functional or physical traits.
